Authors:
Mari Carmen Molina, Ruth Del-Prado, Pradeep Kumar Divakar,
Daniel Sanchez-Mata, Ana Crespo
Title:
Another example of cryptic diversity in lichen-forming fungi:
the new species Parmelia mayi (Ascomycota: Parmeliaceae
Keywords:
Cryptic lineage; new species; Parmelia saxatilis complex;
molecular phylogeny; genetic distance; biogeography
Abstract:
In the last decade the number of cryptic species has
incremented especially in cosmopolitan and or disjunct species in
lichenized fungi. Parmelia saxatilis is one of the most common and
widely distributed species. Recent molecular studies have detected two
species P. ernstiae and P. serrana within P. saxatilis s. lat,
suspecting the existence of considerable genetic diversity that may not
yet expressed at the phenotypic level. Due to the complexity in the P.
saxatilis s. lat group we used this as model to study the species
boundary and identify cryptic lineage. Phylogenetic (Bayes, ML and MP)
and genetic distance approaches has been used to analyze ITS and
Î²-tubulin sequences. Our results confirm the existence of another
cryptic lineage within P. saxatilis s. lat. and is described here as a
new species P mayi. It is an independent, strongly supported reciprocal
monophyletic lineage, phylogenetically distantly related with the
closely resembled morpho-species P. ernstiae, P. saxatilis, and P.
serrana. Morphologically, it is undistinguishable from P. saxatilis but
the new species is separated by molecular phylogeny, pairwise genetic
distance values, having different bioclimatic and biogeographic
distribution pattern and a specific phenolic composition. At present P.
mayi show a restricted distribution in northern Appalachian mountain
territories of North America and found in climatic conditions ranging
from hemiboreal and orotemperate to cryorotemperate utrahyperhumid
thermotypes.
